prompt: A 28-year-old male athlete presents with sudden onset of severe lower back pain after attempting a heavy deadlift at the gym. He describes the pain as sharp and radiating down his left leg to the calf. He also reports tingling and numbness in the left foot. Bending forward or sitting worsens the pain. What is the most likely diagnosis and what red flags should be assessed?

response.likely_diagnosis: Lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy (L5 or S1 nerve root)

reasoning.mechanism_of_injury: Heavy deadlift causes high axial load and flexion/extension stress - common cause of disc herniation
symptoms: Sudden onset of severe lower back pain - typical for acute disc herniation
Sharp pain radiating down left leg to calf (sciatica) - classic nerve root compression
Tingling and numbness in left foot - sensory nerve fiber involvement
Pain worsened by bending forward or sitting - increases intradiscal pressure

differential_diagnoses.notes: Usually less severe, less likely to have radicular symptoms
Neurogenic claudication pattern, more common in older individuals
Can cause radiculopathy but acute onset makes disc herniation more likely
Possible with trauma, less likely without underlying pathology
Surgical emergency - must be ruled out

symptoms_to_assess: Bowel/Bladder dysfunction - incontinence or retention (MOST CRITICAL)
Saddle anesthesia - numbness in perineal area, inner thighs, buttocks, genitals
Significant bilateral leg weakness - difficulty walking or standing
Pain worse at night or unrelieved by rest
History of cancer (breast, lung, prostate, kidney, thyroid)
Pain worse at night or unrelieved by rest

conservative_treatment: Pain management - NSAIDs, muscle relaxants, potentially short-term opioids
management_if_no_red_flags.imaging: MRI if symptoms persist or worsen despite conservative treatment

response.disclaimer: This information is for educational purposes and should not be considered medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional.
